huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
This unit is a General Season hunt unit and is not managed to be a trophy unit but every year a few really nice bucks are taken.  Hunters should be aware of the Ute tribal Lands and learn the boundaries.  Public hunting is not permitted on tribal lands.  There are no CWMUs on this unit.  The unit includes the High Uintas Wilderness area.  The wilderness can provide a remote hunt with few hunters but there are also fewer deer.  Much of the habitat in the high country is fairly sterile without much feed for deer.  It is generally Lodge Pole Pine with little understory.  
Road access on much of the unit is limited to mostly canyon bottoms due to the steepness of the terrain.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for hot, dry, or rainy, lightening, windy or even snowy conditions.  Early snow storms occur often during this hunt.  Most of the time snow will melt off within a day or so.  Be prepared for muddy or snowy road conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 55.8~11000~7000~18–20~19.7~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
General Considerations: This unit is a General Season hunt unit and is not managed to be a trophy unit but every year a few really nice bucks are taken. Hunters should be aware of the Ute Tribal Lands and learn the boundaries. Public hunting is not permitted on Tribal Lands. There are no CWMUs on this unit. The unit includes the High Uintas Wilderness area. The Wilderness can provide a remote hunt with few hunters but there are also less deer. Much of the habitat in the high country is fairly sterile without much feed for deer. It is generally Lodge Pole Pine without much of an understory. Road access on much of the unit is limited to mostly canyon bottoms due to the steepness of the terrain.
Weather Conditions: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season. Be prepared for hot & dry, or rainy, lightening, windy or even snowy conditions. Early snow storms occur often during this hunt. Most of the time snow will melt off within a day or so. Be prepared for muddy or snowy road conditions.
Migration Patterns: Deer on this unit move down in elevation for the winter and they winter primarily on Ute Tribal Lands and on south facing slopes at lower elevation on the Forest Service lands. The deer also move down towards the Tribal Land boundary as soon as they get much hunting pressure. There is very little hunting pressure on the Tribal Lands so some deer have learned to go there as soon as hunting pressure starts.
Mule Deer rut: The mule deer rut usually runs from mid Nov.-mid Dec. so it does not affect this hunt. Recommended areas in the South Slope, Yellowstone: There are numerous suggested areas to hunt on this unit. The Wilderness Area can provide a remote hunt with few hunters but there are also less deer. Much of the habitat in the high country is fairly sterile without much feed for deer. It is generally Lodge Pole Pine without much of an understory. Deer in the Wilderness are generally found above tree line or in small pockets of openings in the lodge pole cover. The larger openings are called parks and can be found on most maps but the smaller openings are scattered across the high country. If you choose to hunt the high country, be prepared for unpredictable weather and lots of rocks. During the hunts most of the deer on the unit are found in the habitat belt where aspen mixes with sagebrush and conifer. That zone across the South Slope is the most productive for deer. Every canyon across the South Slope, Yellowstone has deer and they are of similar quality.

The suggested areas to hunt include (starting on the west side of the unit:
Soapstone area - high elevation, but more road access, closer to the Wasatch Front.
North Fork of the Duchesne- limited road access
Blind Stream - limited road access, tribal land down low, popular area
Log Hollow- must cross Tribal Lands to access, rough roads
Rock Creek - paved road access, steep areas
Pigeon Water - popular area but hunters must be aware of tribal boundary
Bear Wallow - hunters must be aware of tribal boundary, steep terrain
Lake Fork/Moon Lake- paved road access, some private property along the paved road.
Yellowstone - rough roads, need to be aware of Tribal boundary
77 Flat/Burnt Mill- gravel roads, a little flatter area, be aware of Tribal boundary
Dry Gulch- very rough road, steep terrain, be aware of Tribal boundary on the east.
Uinta Canyon- Tribal lands down low, steep Terrain
Elk Horn Loop - gravel roads that go almost to the summit of the Uintas, lots of opportunity to scatter out.
Whiterocks Canyon - Whiterocks river is the eastern unit boundary, steep terrain.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Voluntary: The DWR conducts random surveys for all general season hunts. You may be contacted via phone to participate in this survey.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public lands are all Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley and Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forests.  This unit includes a large portion of the High Uintas Wilderness Area where all motor vehicles are prohibited.  This unit also includes large tracts of Ute tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members.  The tribal lands are mostly the lower elevation sagebrush zone but in some areas they reach up into the aspen/conifer zone.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit too.  Most of the private property is below the tribal boundary but there are several parcels of private property in the canyon bottoms.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Little Montes Creek WMA north of Ballard and Kevin Conway WMA southeast of Myton.  Elk, bear and cougar are rarely found on these WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the forest. There are special restrictions on camping and campfires in certain areas within the Wilderness area. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The main access points for the High Uintas Wilderness include: Uinta Canyon Trailhead, West Fork of Whiterocks Trailhead, Chepeta Trailhead, Lake Fork Trailhead, Yellowstone/Swift Creek Trailhead, Jackson Park road, Dry Gulch road, Rock Creek Trailhead, North Fork of Duchesne Trailhead, and Grandview trailheads
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Kings Peak and Duchesne topo maps
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at:http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The hunt unit does not include the Ute tribal lands.  There is a large tract of Ute tribal trust land that stretches east to west across the South Slope of the Uinta Mountains.  Road access across the tribal land is permitted only across the main access roads to the Forest.  All ATVs are prohibited on tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across tribal Lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Duchesne, Summit, Uintah and Wasatch counties—Boundary begins at SR-87 and US-40 in Duchesne; north on SR-87 to SR-35; northwest on SR-35 to the Provo River; north along this river to North Fork Provo River; north along this river to SR-150; east and north on SR-150 to the Summit-Duchesne county line (summit of the Uinta Mountains) at Hayden Pass; east along the summit of the Uinta Mountains to the Dry Fork-Whiterocks drainage divide; south atop this divide to USFS Trail #025; southwest on this trail to Whiterocks Lake and the East Fork of the Whiterocks River; south along this river to the Whiterocks River; south along this river to the Uinta River; south along this river to the Duchesne River; west along this river to US-40 at Myton; west on US-40 to SR-87 in Duchesne. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Duchesne, Dutch John, Kings Peak, Provo, Salt Lake City, Vernal. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
